did.unittitle: Nelson A. Rockefeller personal papers, Countries, Series E

physdesc.extent: 70 letter boxes, 1 half-letter box, 1 half-legal box

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use note
userestrict.p: The Rockefeller Archive Center has title, copyright, and literary rights in the collection, in so far as it holds them, and has authority to grant permission to cite and publish archival material from the collection.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access note
accessrestrict.p: Open for research with select materials restricted as noted. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC. Material in the Rockefeller family collections that provides the names, correspondence, or activities of living members of the Rockefeller family, and/or documents the net wealth of any Rockefeller family members, is restricted. Researchers interested in accessing digital media (floppy disks, CDs, DVDs, etc.) or audiovisual material (audio cassettes, VHS, etc.) in this collection must use an access surrogate. The original items may not be accessed because of preservation concerns. To request an access surrogate be made, or if you are unsure if there is an access surrogate, please contact an archivist.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The Countries Series is arranged alphabetically by country name. Subject files are arranged alphabetically thereunder.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains Nelson A. Rockefeller's correspondence with private individuals and representatives of institutions and governments in 87 foreign countries. With some exceptions, this material consists mainly of financial appeals from individuals and institutions. Appeals from individuals include requests for money for such things as starting a business, traveling to the United States, or publishing a book. The range of institutions includes churches, universities, health centers, and businesses. Because Mr. Rockefeller followed his family's philanthropic tradition of aiding people through institutions rather than individually, nearly all of the personal appeals were declined. Only those institutional appeals that fell within Mr. Rockefeller's areas of interest were favorably answered. Most of the declination letters were written by members of Mr. Rockefeller's staff on his behalf.

While some scattered documents are dated as early as 1931, the bulk of the material covers the period from 1945 to 1971. In accordance with Rockefeller family office filing procedures, appeals from individuals dated prior to 1958 were discarded by the family office staff prior to inclusion in the archive.

The material consists of all manner of correspondence and sometimes includes newspaper clippings or photographs. There are also background reports on individuals and institutions in which Mr. Rockefeller took an interest. Much of the correspondence, including the appeals, is from his foreign friends and acquaintances. Some of them sent Mr. Rockefeller reports on political and economic conditions in various countries, particularly emerging nations and developing countries. Correspondence with friends and acquaintances also includes invitations, regrets, announcements, and acknowledgements.

More than half of the material in this series is from individuals in Latin America, reflecting Mr. Rockefeller's deep interest in that region. These individuals include business leaders, political leaders, diplomats, and artists. The Latin American-related material complements other series in the Nelson A. Rockefeller Papers, namely Series B: AIA-IBEC Files and Series O: Washington, DC Files. Together, these materials offer a nearly complete record of Rockefeller's interest in the economic, political, and cultural affairs of Latin America.

Banco Moreira Salles annual reports of 1957 and 1966. Copies of Ambassador's speeches.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

L. Yuan, director, and NAR re: possible John D. Rockefeller, Jr. support for library; declined. NAR thanks to General Yu for Chinese government honor. Copy of Asian edition, "Reader's Digest" sent.

NAR felt the aims of American Federation Movement should, if possible, be fulfilled by the United Nations.

Personal correspondence, correspondence re: International Basic Economy Corporation (President not informed on), Brazilian-Colombian relations; Lleras letter to NAR re: his work as rector of private university; resignation from the Pan American Union (copy of speech), correspondence re: Inter-American Cooperation; correspondence re: Lleras work on magazine "Semana." Clippings re: Lleras career.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

Correspondence with NAR as Coordinator of Inter-American Affairs on Colombian policy at Chapultepec Conference, 1945, re: guaranteeing borders of South American nations. Letter to NAR from Santos re: South American international politics, dangers of Peronism. NAR correspondence with President Santos of Colombia on Rockefeller projects being set up in Brazil and Venezuela; NAR hopes for greater consultation among nations of the Americas; President Santos letter telling of revealing talks with Franklin Delano Roosevelt on security of South America. Personal correspondence, clipping of 1950. Letter to editor of "New York Times."

Excerpts from 1948 interview in which Zuleta notes decline of United States interest in Latin America. Zuleta comments on International Basic Economy Corporation. Zuleta report on difficulty Latin Americans had in working with United States at UNO conference in 1946.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Memorandum of conversation between Mexican President Cardenas and NAR in the presence of Mr. Walter Douglas and his secretary, October 14-15, 1939. In memo NAR reports Cardenas as saying he foresaw little hope of a settlement with the oil companies, that expropriation of oil properties was an effort to lift Mexican morale. Discussion also included Rockefeller Foundation problems in working with the Mexican Health Department. Also, NAR handwritten notes and draft of an extensive memorandum to State Department reporting Mexico's willingness to compensate oil companies and agreement by the companies and Mexico to hold talks.
